To extrapolate the revenue MTN Nigeria is likely to generate from its mobile money business in Africa’s most populous nation, BusinessDay proceeded to analyze the data by Tellimer, a global technology, information, and data provider, that surveyed mobile money penetration (defined as mobile money users as a percentage of total subscriber base) across various African telcos and markets.
As expected, Safaricom had the highest penetration (71percent), given its dominance and the positive trend for mobile money in Kenya.
“This means that it will be very difficult for MTN Nigeria to replicate M-Pesa’s success in Kenya or that of its fellow MTN Group subsidiary in Ghana,” Omole said.
The central bank had in 2019 granted approvals to Hope PSB, Money Master PSB and 9PSB.

headline: Foreign investors prefer Nigerian banks’ Eurobonds to their stocks
summarized_story:
Foreign investors can’t get enough of Nigerian banks’ Eurobonds but won’t touch their stocks with a ten-foot pole.
First, it was Access Bank and now United Bank for Africa (UBA) that has issued Eurobonds that ended up oversubscribed by foreign investors, a sign of strong investor confidence in Nigeria’s top banks.
For the UBA Eurobond, investors will receive 6.75 percent every year for five years.
The lack of interest in banking stocks, once favourites of foreign investors, is due to challenges with accessing foreign exchange, which has made many wary of holding naira assets.
Although dollar liquidity has been improving in recent times and is expected to improve even further as banks tap the Eurobond market, foreign investors remain largely on the side-lines.

headline: Lagos streets turn outlets for fast food
summarized_story:

Apart from the QSRs going into smaller formats, FMCGs now package their products into smaller sachets to target the larger segment of the economy.
“A lot of consumer food service operators are now trying to explore the format of miniaturization.
Although it is an interesting opportunity, Uzo advises that QSRs should not copy each other or else their business could shut down.

headline: National Housing Programme: Nigerians invited to apply as Fashola launches portal for sale of houses
summarized_story:
Nigerians can now apply for houses built under the current Federal Government’s National Housing Programme (NHP) in 34 states of the country following the launch, Friday, of the portal by the Minister of Works and Housing, Babatunde Fashola, through which interested members of the public could apply for allocation.
The minister told his audience, “We converge here just to introduce a portal on which the National Housing Programme pilot will be offered for sale to the public.

headline: Nigerian govt to auction N150bn bonds in November
summarized_story:

headline: Tordue Salem: NUJ Faults Police Narrative, Demands Independent Inquiry, Autopsy
summarized_story:
The FCT Council of the Nigeria Union of Journalists (NUJ) has tasked the Federal Government to empanel an independent probe into circumstances surrounding the death of Vanguard Newspapers reporter, Tordue Salem.
Salem went missing on October 13, 2021 in Abuja and was reported dead on November 11 by the newspaper he worked with for several years.
“The death of Mr. Tordue Salem opens another dark chapter for journalism and journalists in Nigeria and we are grievously saddened by it.
“It is in this regard that we urge President Muhammadu Buhari to order for an independent inquiry into the tragic end of Mr. Tordue.
“The NUJ also demands for an independent autopsy so as to allay the fears of thousands of journalists and citizens across the country that indeed the late Mr. Tordue was a victim of a hit and run driver,” it said.

The pulling out parade was part of activities of the ongoing Infantry Corps annual leadership lectures and biennial reunion, holding at the Infantry Corps Centre in Jaji Military Cantonment, Kaduna State.

headline: Many die as two buses burst into flames after collision,
summarized_story:

The local gin in the J5 bus was said to have aided the fire which later smoldered after the head-on collusion with the accident causing a traffic gridlock for more than one hour at the axis.

headline: BREAKING: FG Increases Prices Of Electricity Meters
summarized_story:
Beginning November 15, 2021, the federal government will hike the price of single-phase and three-phase electricity meters.
The Nigerian Electricity Regulatory Commission released a circular on November 11, 2021, addressed to managing directors, all electricity distribution firms, and all meter asset providers.
The circular was titled ‘Review of the unit price of end-use meters under the Meter Asset Provider and National Mass Metering Regulations’ and has the reference number NERC/REG/MAP/GEN/751/2.
The regulator increased the price of a single-phase meter from its existing price of N44,896.17 to a revised price of N58,661.69 in the document.
It also raised the price of a three-phase meter from N82,855.19 to N109,684.36 (updated rate).

headline: US Journalist Jailed for 11 Years in Army-Ruled Myanmar
summarized_story:
A court in military-ruled Myanmar on Friday jailed American journalist Danny Fenster for 11 years, his lawyer and his employer said, despite U.S. calls for his release from what it said was unjust detention.
“There is absolutely no basis to convict Danny of these charges,” said Thomas Kean, editor-in-chief of Frontier Myanmar, one of the country’s top independent news outlets.
“The junta’s rationale for this outrageous, rights abusing sentence is first to shock and intimidate all remaining Burmese journalists inside Myanmar by punishing a foreign journalist this way,” he said.
Independent media has been accused by the junta of incitement.
Myanmar authorities overlooked Fenster in a recent amnesty for hundreds of people detained over anti-junta protests, which included some journalists.

headline: Azikiwe Against Biafran Tyranny – Trending With Ojy Okpe
summarized_story:
The arrest of 14 persons in connection to the raid of the home of Mary Odili, a justice of the Supreme Court has generated mixed reactions.
During a press briefing on Thursday, Frank Mba, the police, public relations officer, said a fake chief superintendent of police, an Islamic scholar and a journalist were among the 14 persons arrested.
A video Of Dr. Nnamdi Azikiwe, the first president of Nigeria, speaking at the Nigerian High Commission in London, with a message to the Igbos during the Civil War in 1969, to turn away from the leaders of Biafra who misled them into supporting an enterprise that had brought them widespread suffering has resurfaced online and is making the rounds on social media.
Meanwhile, Eunice Ngozi Onuegbusi, the woman who was seen in a viral video rejecting money from agents of the All Progressives Congress, after they tried to pay her and a group of other women the sum of N5,000 each, to vote for their party on November 6th during the Anambra Governorship election; on Thursday was awarded the sum of N1 million by Willy Obiano, the governor of Anambra State.
The Governor thanked her for her courage, saying even though she knew the money could buy her temporary relief, she remained loyal And voted according to her conscience .

headline: Toshiba Plans to Split into Three Firms, Rejects Calls to Go Private
summarized_story:
Japan’s Toshiba Corp outlined plans on Friday to split into three independent companies, seeking to appease activist shareholders calling for a radical overhaul after years of scandal.
A break-up would run counter to calls by some shareholders for Toshiba to be taken private.
RETURNS FOR SHAREHOLDERSAs part of the overhaul, Toshiba aims to return around 100 billion yen ($875 million) to shareholders over the next two financial years.
Other assets that will continue to be held by Toshiba include its stake in Toshiba Tec Corp (6588.T), a maker of printing and retail information systems.
Two years later, it secured a $5.4 billion cash injection from 30-plus overseas investors that helped avoid a delisting but brought in activist shareholders including Elliott Management, Third Point and Farallon.

headline: Nigeria Police Parade 14 Suspects over Invasion of Justice Odili’s Residence
summarized_story:
The Nigeria Police on Thursday paraded 14 suspects allegedly involved in the invasion of the Abuja residence of Supreme Court Justice, Mrs. Mary Odili.
THISDAY disowned one of the suspects, Mr. Stanley Nkwazema, who claimed to be a staff and contributing editor of the newspaper.
Nkwazema claimed he was investigating an exclusive story.
Mba said all the suspects attended all the meetings before the invasion and were all there on the night of the invasion.
“Contrary to his claim, Mr. Nkwazema is neither a staff of THISDAY nor a Contributing Editor.
